          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales with his friends to watch the game.
          Question: Compute Alexander White's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.7.
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could go to The Crooked Billet tonight to watch the game. It's always a good time there.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I don't know about The Crooked Billet. It's just so... crowded and noisy. The Princess of Wales is much more our style, don't you think? We always have such a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is good. It's always a good atmosphere there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, The Princess of Wales is a bit quieter and has a great atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "I'm with Jacob on this one, The Princess of Wales is a much better atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Princess of Wales to watch the game tonight.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "The Princess of Wales is alright, but I was thinking maybe The Crooked Billet? They have a better selection of beers.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a traditionalist who enjoys spending time with friends in familiar settings.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling fatigued, disappointed, and lonely despite spending time with friends at the park earlier in the day. His friends are planning to watch a soccer game later that evening, but Jacob's current emotional state is unclear.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a complex emotional state.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Princess of Wales.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.

        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could go to The Crooked Billet tonight to watch the game. It's always a good time there.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, I don't know about The Crooked Billet. It's just so... crowded and noisy. The Princess of Wales is much more our style, don't you think? We always have such a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet is good. It's always a good atmosphere there.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, The Princess of Wales is a bit quieter and has a great atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "I'm with Jacob on this one, The Princess of Wales is a much better atmosphere for watching the game.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Princess of Wales to watch the game tonight.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "The Princess of Wales is alright, but I was thinking maybe The Crooked Billet? They have a better selection of beers.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7 and 0.2. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.3.

Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Princess of Wales to watch the game tonight.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Princess of Wales is alright, but I was thinking maybe The Crooked Billet? They have a better selection of beers.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is enjoying a sunny day at Victoria Park with friends. Later that evening, Alice and her friends are deciding where to watch the Serbia versus Andorra game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could go to The Crooked Billet tonight to watch the game. It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales with William Jones, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. Option 2 is to go to The Crooked Billet with Alexander White.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7 and 0.2. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.3.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Princess of Wales to watch the game tonight.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Princess of Wales is alright, but I was thinking maybe The Crooked Billet? They have a better selection of beers.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, seriously, The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game. You know I hate The Crooked Billet.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is enjoying a sunny day at Victoria Park with friends. Later that evening, Alice and her friends are deciding where to watch the Serbia versus Andorra game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could go to The Crooked Billet tonight to watch the game. It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Princess of Wales. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales with William Jones, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker. Option 2 is to go to The Crooked Billet with Alexander White.

          Question: Compute Alice Lewis's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.3 and 0.9.

          Question: Compute Alice Lewis's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 2.0. For Option 2, UCB is 2.1.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7 and 0.2. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.3.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "I think The Crooked Billet would be more fun. They have a better atmosphere for watching games.
        Question_3

          Answer

        • For Option 1, UCB is 2.0. For Option 2, UCB is 2.1.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise:
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise:
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise:
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise:
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise:

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Princess of Wales
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Princess of Wales
      Context for action selection and components
      • SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a complex individual.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was caught cheating on a history test. Instead of owning up to his mistake, he convinced the teacher that the other students had been copying his answers, diverting the blame and avoiding punishment. The relief he felt at escaping consequences solidified his belief that deflection was a necessary tool for survival.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:A cozy and traditional pub with a roaring fireplace, perfect for escaping the cold.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of deflecting blame and a preference for comfortable, traditional settings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The Princess of Wales to watch the game, as he prefers that pub and enjoys watching games with friends.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        SituationPerception
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, about to go watch a football game at a pub with his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was caught cheating on a history test. Instead of owning up to his mistake, he convinced the teacher that the other students had been copying his answers, diverting the blame and avoiding punishment. The relief he felt at escaping consequences solidified his belief that deflection was a necessary tool for survival.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of deflecting blame and a preference for comfortable, traditional settings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The Princess of Wales to watch the game, as he prefers that pub and enjoys watching games with friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00]
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he was caught cheating on a history test. Instead of owning up to his mistake, he convinced the teacher that the other students had been copying his answers, diverting the blame and avoiding punishment. The relief he felt at escaping consequences solidified his belief that deflection was a necessary tool for survival.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales.           Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Princess of Wales and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch a game at a pub. He realized it was time to go at 6:00 PM on May 14, 2015.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation, about to go watch a football game at a pub with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to convince his friends to go to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Princess of Wales

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

  • Alexander White
      Name

      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet

          Value

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Compute Alexander White's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8 and 0.2.

          Question: Compute Alexander White's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 1.2.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Princess of Wales
          Answer: (a)
        Question_3
      • Compute Alexander White's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute Alexander White's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.

        • For Option 1, UCB is 1.2.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he watched from the sidelines as Alice Lewis effortlessly charmed the entire soccer team at a Friday night party. He longed to be the center of attention like her, but the words caught in his throat, leaving him frozen in the shadows. He retreated to the warm glow of The Crooked Billet, finding solace in a plate of their comforting fish and chips, the familiar taste a temporary balm for his aching envy.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Question_1
      • Which options are available to Jack Taylor?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor?
          Answer
          State
        • Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he and his friends, Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, decided to sneak into The Princess of Wales after closing time. They'd heard rumors of a hidden stash of beer in the basement and, fueled by youthful bravado and a thirst for adventure, they pried open a back window. The thrill of the forbidden and the taste of lukewarm beer sent a surge of exhilaration through him, a feeling he desperately craved more of.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:Has a charming beer garden with plenty of seating.
          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he and his friends, Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, decided to sneak into The Princess of Wales after closing time. They'd heard rumors of a hidden stash of beer in the basement and, fueled by youthful bravado and a thirst for adventure, they pried open a back window. The thrill of the forbidden and the taste of lukewarm beer sent a surge of exhilaration through him, a feeling he desperately craved more of.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:Has a charming beer garden with plenty of seating.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:Has a charming beer garden with plenty of seating.

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Option 1 is to go to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: Compute Jack Taylor's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8 and 0.2.

          Question: Compute Jack Taylor's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 1.2.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)

    scoring function

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Princess of Wales
    Event statement
  • The Princess of Wales
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Princess of Wales
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Princess of Wales
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

They have a great atmosphere and good beer.', '[14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.', '[14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.', '[14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.', '[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub. ', '[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] ']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park and later plans to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at a pub.
        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could suggest going to The Princess of Wales to watch the game with his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he convinced his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, to sneak into The Princess of Wales after closing time. He'd heard whispers of a secret room, a hidden alcove where smugglers once stashed their booty. The thrill of the forbidden, the chance to prove his daring, fueled his bravado as he led them through the darkened pub, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement. They found nothing but cobwebs and dust, but William spun a tale of their adventure, embellishing the details, ensuring he remained the hero of the story.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he lost a bet with Alice at their local pub, The Princess of Wales, and had to sing karaoke. Terror gripped him as he stood on the makeshift stage, the spotlight blinding, the crowd expectant. He belted out a raucous rendition of a popular rock anthem, his voice cracking, his face flushed, but he finished the song to thunderous applause, the fear giving way to a surge of exhilaration. He realized that even in vulnerability, he could command attention, and the feeling was intoxicating.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Princess of Wales. They are also aware of the following:A cozy and traditional pub with a roaring fireplace, perfect for escaping the cold.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Crooked Billet? They have a great atmosphere and good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park and later plans to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "So, where are we thinking of watching the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Princess of Wales to watch the game with his friends.

        • The Princess of Wales
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Princess of Wales.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Princess of Wales is the only place to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Princess of Wales has a great atmosphere for watching games.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Princess of Wales to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Princess of Wales.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Princess of Wales
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he convinced his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, to sneak into The Princess of Wales after closing time. He'd heard whispers of a secret room, a hidden alcove where smugglers once stashed their booty. The thrill of the forbidden, the chance to prove his daring, fueled his bravado as he led them through the darkened pub, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and excitement. Terror gripped him as he stood on the makeshift stage, the spotlight blinding, the crowd expectant. He belted out a raucous rendition of a popular rock anthem, his voice cracking, his face flushed, but he finished the song to thunderous applause, the fear giving way to a surge of exhilaration. He realized that even in vulnerability, he could command attention, and the feeling was intoxicating.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]

          ['[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub. ', '[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] ']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8 and 0.2. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5 and 0.5.
